review.title: Source-Sensitive Belief Change
review.abstract: The AGM model is the most remarkable framework for modeling belief revision. However, it is not perfect in all aspects. Paraconsistent belief revision, multi-agent belief revision and non-prioritized belief revision are three different extensions to AGM to address three important criticisms applied to it. In this article, we propose a framework based on AGM that takes a position in each of these categories. Also, we discuss some features of our framework and study the satisfiability of AGM postulates in this new context.

sections.heading: 3 Source-sensitive Belief Changes
sections.text: In the original Annual General Meeting manuscripts, contraction, expansion and revision are considered to be the three most important types of faith changes that happen to a state of belief in relation to an input. Contraction is defined to eliminate an existing faith and define expansion along with revision to add a new faith. The difference between revision and expansion is that the result must be consistent in the former, whereas expansion consistency is not a constraint. By changing our view from consistency to paraconsistency, motivations for adopting revision as the main type of faith change no longer have reasonable supports and motivations. As Tanaka ([26]) has investigated, revision collapses expansion through the use of paraconsistent logics in the AGM model. Therefore, it also seems very permissible to agree with this result in our multi-source environment. sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced a new framework called source-sensitive belief change, based on AGM, to address three criticisms that apply to the AGM model: single-agent environment, primacy of input and consistency criterion. We specified our position in each extended topic for these criticisms, so-called multi-agent faith change, non-prioritized faith change and paraconsistent faith change. Of course, there are some similarities and relationships between our model and other proposals ([10], [23], [24] and [25]) in these areas, and there are also several motivations, characteristics and characteristics that are exclusive in the recent framework. As has been shown, the changes that we have applied to the creation of our desired model have led to persistent AGM postulates, as far as possible. However, some of the definitions we use are redefined and with very general attributes, so ways to improve them are open and need to be explored.
